title: Introduction to Digital Literacy
description: Master the fundamentals of digital technology, computer systems, and online safety

sets.title: Computer Fundamentals
sets.description: Understanding computer hardware, software, and basic operations

cards.back: A computer is an electronic device that processes data according to instructions, performing calculations and operations automatically using binary code (0s and 1s).

cards.front: What is the CPU and what does it do?
cards.back: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) is the brain of the computer that executes instructions, performs calculations, and manages data flow between components.

cards.front: What is RAM and why is it important?
cards.back: RAM (Random Access Memory) is temporary storage that holds data and programs currently in use. It's fast but volatile - data is lost when power is turned off.

cards.front: What is the difference between RAM and storage?
cards.back: RAM is fast, temporary memory for active programs, while storage (HDD/SSD) is slower but permanent memory for files and programs when not in use.
The motherboard is the main circuit board that connects all computer components, including CPU, RAM, storage, and expansion cards.
An operating system is software that manages computer hardware and software resources, providing a user interface and common services for applications.

cards.front: What are the main functions of an operating system?
cards.back: Process management, memory management, file system management, device management, security, and user interface.

cards.front: What is the difference between system software and application software?
cards.back: System software manages hardware and provides platform for applications (OS, drivers), while application software performs specific tasks for users (word processors, games).
A driver is software that allows the operating system to communicate with hardware devices like printers, graphics cards, or USB devices.
Binary code is the language computers use, consisting of only two digits: 0 and 1. Each digit is called a bit, and 8 bits make a byte.

sets.title: Internet & World Wide Web
sets.description: Understanding how the internet works and web technologies

cards.back: The Internet is a global network of interconnected computers and servers that allows information sharing and communication worldwide using standardized protocols.

cards.front: What is the difference between Internet and World Wide Web?
cards.back: The Internet is the network infrastructure, while the World Wide Web is a service that runs on the Internet using HTTP protocol to share web pages.
A web browser is software that interprets HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to display web pages and allows users to navigate the World Wide Web.

cards.front: What is a URL and what are its components?
cards.back: A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) consists of protocol (http/https), domain name, path, and optional parameters. Example: https://www.example.com/page?id=123

cards.front: What is DNS and what does it do?
cards.back: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-readable domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.
A search engine is a web service that indexes web pages and allows users to find information by entering keywords or phrases.
HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is the protocol for transferring web data. HTTPS adds encryption (SSL/TLS) for secure communication.
A cookie is a small text file stored by websites on your computer to remember preferences, login status, and track user behavior.
A cache is temporary storage that stores frequently accessed data to improve loading speed and reduce server requests.
Bandwidth is the maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over a network connection in a given time period, usually measured in bits per second.

sets.title: Digital Communication
sets.description: Understanding email, messaging, and online communication tools

cards.front: What is email and how does it work?
cards.back: Email (electronic mail) is a method of exchanging digital messages using SMTP protocol. Messages are sent through email servers to recipients.

cards.front: What are the components of an email address?
cards.back: An email address consists of a username, @ symbol, and domain name. Example: user@example.com
Instant messaging allows real-time text communication between users over the internet, often with additional features like file sharing and video calls.
VoIP (Voice over Internet Protocol) allows voice communication over the internet instead of traditional phone lines, like Skype or Zoom.
Video conferencing allows face-to-face communication over the internet using video and audio technology, enabling remote meetings and collaboration.
Social media are online platforms that allow users to create, share, and interact with content and connect with others through profiles and networks.
A blog is a regularly updated website or web page, typically run by an individual or small group, written in an informal or conversational style.
A forum is an online discussion site where people can hold conversations in the form of posted messages, organized by topics or categories.
Netiquette is the set of rules for proper behavior and courtesy when communicating online, including being respectful and avoiding spam.
A digital footprint is the trail of data you leave behind when using the internet, including social media posts, search history, and online purchases.

sets.title: Cybersecurity & Online Safety
sets.description: Protecting yourself and your data online

cards.back: Cybersecurity is the practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks, damage, or unauthorized access.

cards.front: What is a password and why is it important?
cards.back: A password is a secret combination of characters used to verify identity and protect accounts from unauthorized access. It's the first line of defense.
A strong password is at least 12 characters long, includes uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, special characters, and avoids common words.
2FA adds an extra layer of security by requiring a second form of verification (like a code sent to your phone) in addition to your password.
Phishing is a cyber attack where criminals impersonate legitimate organizations to trick users into revealing personal information or clicking malicious links.
Malware is malicious software designed to harm computers, steal data, or gain unauthorized access. Types include viruses, worms, trojans, and ransomware.
A firewall is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
Encryption is the process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access. Only those with the correct key can decrypt the information.
A VPN (Virtual Private Network) creates a secure, encrypted connection over the internet, protecting your privacy and allowing secure access to networks.
Identity theft occurs when someone steals your personal information to commit fraud, such as opening accounts or making purchases in your name.

sets.title: Digital Literacy Skills
sets.description: Essential skills for navigating the digital world

cards.back: Digital literacy is the ability to use digital technology, communication tools, and networks to access, manage, integrate, evaluate, and create information.
Information literacy is the ability to find, evaluate, and use information effectively, including determining credibility and relevance of sources.
Media literacy is the ability to access, analyze, evaluate, and create media messages, understanding how media influences society and individuals.

cards.front: What is critical thinking in digital context?
cards.back: Critical thinking involves analyzing digital information, questioning sources, evaluating evidence, and making informed decisions about online content.
Digital citizenship is the responsible use of technology, including ethical behavior, respecting others online, and contributing positively to digital communities.
Digital etiquette (netiquette) involves following proper behavior guidelines when communicating online, including being respectful and considerate.
Digital access refers to the ability to use technology and the internet, including having the necessary devices, connectivity, and skills.
Digital commerce involves buying and selling goods and services online, understanding e-commerce platforms, payment methods, and consumer rights.
Digital law involves understanding legal and ethical issues related to technology use, including copyright, privacy laws, and cybercrime.

cards.front: What is digital health and wellness?
cards.back: Digital health and wellness involves maintaining physical and psychological well-being in a digital world, including managing screen time and online stress.
